player_decision.reason: Call to see a flop with 8c Tc in the small blind vs a single opponent. It has decent backdoor potential and a low investment (call 5 to compete for a 20 pot). Folding would give up the pot and raising would be too aggressive given the opponent's wide BB range and large stack advantage.
Heads-up vs a small blind limp, Q9 suited is strong; raise to isolate and take initiative. 3.5x puts pressure while keeping stacks playable.

We have a suited connector (Tc8c) on a heads-up pot with a 35 bet preflop. Calling 25 to see the flop gives us pot odds (~31%) and backdoor flush/straight potential without committing a huge portion of our stack.

SPR is <1 versus villain (60 into 70). On a paired, draw-heavy flop our Q9d has little equity and poor playability versus a likely shove. Checking keeps the pot small and lets us realize backdoor equity without committing into a range that calls/jams often.

You have a four-out straight draw (8-10 with 6-7 on board). Calling preserves your Equity and gives you a chance to hit on turn or river, while raising would likely commit you with a marginal hand on a paired board.

Pot is 70 with opponent at 60 behind; our Q9 has a gutshot and some showdown value. Checking keeps the pot controlled and realizes equity without risking committing versus a short stack on a paired, draw-heavy board.

With 8cTc on a 7s-6s-7h-5d board and only a backdoor straight draw, there isn’t enough equity to justify a raise or all-in. Calling to see the river keeps pot manageable and lets me realize any runner-runner outs if they appear.
Value bet for calls from worse pairs on a missed flush board; avoid overbet that may fold out second-best hands.

You have two pair (Queens and Sevens) on the river (Qd on board, Qs in hand). Pot is 110; you must call 40 to continue, which gives pot odds of 40 to win 150 ≈ 26.7% break-even. With plausible villain ranges (and two clean outs to trips: Qh, Qc; plus runouts that can give you a full house or better), your equity is at or above break-even. Folding is too weak given the situation; shoving all-in is overly risky with 60 chips left.
